comment_text: if one day we figure out that all or most dinosaurs had feathers, then Jurassic Park and all the illustrations up to that time will look like a bunch of plucked chickens. Just think how different owls look without their feathers.

Pterosaurs had feathers? Tell me again about these maned chinese dragons and feathered serpents.

Long winding tunnels for nostrils that remove heat from air? Tell me again about these fire-breathing dragons.
FYI, the kylo in Ankylosaur is pronounced the same as Kylo in Kylo Ren.

Even if the fibers are unique to Pterosaurs, almost nothing in nature is made from scratch. But re-purposed older structures, since evolution is about getting old genes to do new things. So the last common ancestor of non-avian dinosaurs and the Pterosaurs, or all large reptiles that lived along side them. Inherited some proto-feather like skin feature/type and as they followed different evolutionary paths so to did their proto-feathers. Another thing to remember, when they say feather they don't mean pretty much anything on modern avian-dinosaurs (birds) but skin coverings that are made of the same stuff and appear to be less advanced or just less complex versions of what we see today.

With that said, I have seen conservative drawings of all dinosaurs with some type of skin covering instead of bear scales. It makes it look like the age of the dinosaurs is an alien planet, with how different everything looks.

Pterosaurs are not related to dinosaurs. Pterosaurs arose from Longisquama, Sharovipteryx and Cosesaurus, all of which have bristles, fibers, extradermal membranes, etc... by convergence... and a long list of skeletal traits shared with pterosaurs alone. All of these taxa were omitted by this study. More details and fossil pix here: https://pterosaurheresies.wordpress.com/2018/12/18/pterosaur-pycnofibres-revisited-yang-et-al-2018/

So the common ancestor of ornithodira or avemetatarsalia might have had feathers, but the common ancestor of archosauria definitely didn’t have feathers, right? If there’s a possibility of fuzzy pseudosuchians, I NEED TO KNOW

Just so that you all know, pterosaurs aren't actually dinosaurs, even though all our prehistoric playsets would imply that. Pterosauromorpha are a sister clade to Dinosauromorpha, both of the parent clade Avemetatarsalia, which includes all archosaurs that are closer to birds than to crocodiles (Pseudosuchia). What this recent finding implies, is that since both pterosaurs and dinosaurs share feather-like structures, then the origin of feathers comes from their parent clade.

why can't we compare the composition of dinosaur feathers and pycnofibres to see if there are similarities.

You conveniently omitted that the mrca of ornithischians and coelorosaurs is the mrca of all dinosaurs. If the mrca of ornithischians and coelorosaurs had feathers, then all dinosaurs had genes to make feathers. This research doesn't suggest that all dinosaurs had genes for feathers; that was already established. It suggests that other archosaurs that are closely related to dinosaurs and pterosaurs may have had feathers.

Could the fibers on Pterosaurs have been linked to nerve endings to help them gauge wind speed and direction to help in flying and soaring? It is known that Pterosaurs had enlarged areas of the brain similar to those of birds that are used fo flying. In fact Pterosaurs brain areas associate with flying were bigger than modern day birds' are.
